Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: Optimizing the Human-Machine System for Citizen Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project investigates optimal human-machine collaboration for analysis of large, complex data sets. The project uses advances in machine learning to develop new citizen science system infrastructure to be built into Zooniverse --- a large, open-source platform for online citizen science. Citizen Science is an established method for distributed analysis of large quantities of data in which online volunteers help with tasks requiring human pattern recognition. An example is identifying morphology of galaxies in the Galaxy Zoo project. Much larger data sets are looming on the horizon. Designing a human-machine system to accelerate labeling of known classes at the same time as solving the problem of detecting interesting anomalies (suggesting new phenomena) requires answering several crucial research questions about how humans and machines best complement one another. Since the project's new techniques will be incorporated into Zooniverse, they will be available to all for use in citizen science projects across many disciplines. Additional benefits of this project include engaging over 2 million members of the public who participate in citizen science through Zooniverse, engaging young women in University of Minnesota computer science coding camps, and providing year-long capstone projects for Data Science Masters program students to engage in real-world research while preparing them for careers in data science. <br/><br/>This project will carry out a detailed investigation of load balancing between human and machine classifiers, optimizing for the speed, accuracy, completeness or purity required by the domain research for a given task. The research program follows two thrusts: (1) Classification Efficiency Studies to optimize the classification efficiency of known classes across multiple domains and task types; and (2) Systematized Serendipity Studies to increase the efficiency of discovery, including detection of rare instances, unusual findings, and new classes. The project develops new infrastructure that builds on the existing capabilities of the Zooniverse citizen science platform through two modules: (1) Machine Integration Infrastructure to readily incorporate and combine machines on projects to increase classification efficiency as well as explore the machine-driven component of systematized serendipity; and (2) Leveling-up Strategies for Volunteers to enable human-driven identification of emergent classes. Ultimately, the human- and machine-driven mechanisms will be joined to form a combined human-machine system that will be tested for its ability to identify unknown, rare, or difficult to identify classes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Citizen Science, a powerful method for large-scale data analysis, faces the challenge of handling increasingly massive datasets. Our project, a collaboration between Zooniverse teams at the Adler Planetarium, University of Minnesota (UMN), and University of Oxford, investigated a new human-machine system responsive to the competing tasks of efficiently classifying known knowns while also creating space for serendipitous discovery.

The research was carried out in the context of the Zooniverse, the world’s largest platform for people-powered research, with 2.6 million participants around the world and over 400 projects across the disciplines launched to date, from astronomy to zoology, cancer research to climate science, arts and humanities. 

Intellectual Merit:

The research program was divided into two main objectives for the combined human-machine system:

  • Classification Efficiency Studies to optimize the classification efficiency of nominal or known known classes across multiple domains and task types;
  • Systematized Serendipity Studies to increase the efficiency of detecting diverse anomalies beyond the usual statistically inferred false positives. 

Several novel results have emerged. For example, the Galaxy Zoo Weird & Wonderful experiment led to the development of a new generative anomaly detection pipeline applied to the 2.5 million images from the Subaru Hyper-Suprime Cam survey. The pipeline fed into a Zooniverse project through which volunteers analyzed grids of images, flagging which ones they found particularly interesting. Preliminary results suggest a 4/5th reduction in samples needed to be viewed by volunteers towards finding scientifically interesting anomalies. This reduction in human effort is critical in our efforts to take full advantage of our enormous data sets while still keeping space for serendipitous discovery of the unknown unknowns. As another example, the 3D-Anomaly Identification and Modeling Engine (3D-AnIME) successfully identified anomalous regions in galaxies, offering an innovative approach for unsupervised identification of active galaxies. Implementing Leveling-up strategies for volunteers on Zooniverse (in which the task becomes progressively more complex as participants unlock the next level up) demonstrated both efficiency gains and motivation gains. Additionally, the project developed general-purpose image segmentation models, showcasing strong transferability and efficiency gains. To date, the project has resulted in a half dozen peer-reviewed journal articles (as well as an additional eleven indirect articles), over a dozen presentations at conferences, and several outreach presentations targeting underrepresented groups in STEM. 

In order to carry out the above research efforts, a major component of this grant was to expand the capabilities of the Zooniverse platform, its powerful API, modern front-end, and cloud-based architecture. A particular focus was to further build out Caesar, a secondary Rails module initially developed with prior NSF funding. Caesar is now fully featured to orchestrate and take action based on the incoming flow of classification data and machine information. This includes communication with external systems to integrate machine learning results and send information back, tracking Zooniverse participant quality and effort, and taking action based on combined human and machine responses. 

While the infrastructure development effort funded through this grant is complete, our UMN colleagues will continue to deepen the research impacts and discoveries through a final no-cost extension year, as well as researchers more broadly utilizing these machine learning integration tools and infrastructure within the Zooniverse to unlock their data and accelerate discovery.

Broader Impacts:

The Zooniverse is an open-source platform guided by principles of accessibility and inclusion. In integrating machine learning into our infrastructure and projects, we strive to be open and transparent with participants about the role of machine learning and the interplay and complementarity between the machine and human efforts in our system. Much remains to be learned and improved upon, but this project was an important step. Zooniverse provides an impactful pathway for bridging the gap between science and society, including in lifting the veil on how machine learning works, the role machine learning plays in modern science, and the continued importance of humans in the loop. Optimizing for efficiency and discovery while maintaining focus on human engagement, our project sets best practices for engaging the public in scientific research, fostering a symbiotic relationship between the public and scientific discovery.

Our project also facilitated a range of opportunities for training and professional development:

  • Students and postdocs expanded their expertise in machine learning, software development, and mentoring, as well as developing group leadership skills and experience working in a collaborative, multidisciplinary team.

  • Zooniverse developers worked closely with data scientists as well as domain experts in the development of the infrastructure implemented on the Zooniverse platform, growing their knowledge, expertise, and ability to collaborate across disciplinary boundaries.
